metadata.case_name: Gopal Singh and Sardar Singh v. Mst. Biro and her sons

facts.text: Harnam Singh owned the property in dispute and died before 2nd November 1914.
On 2nd November 1914, after Harnam Singh's death, his daughter Mst. Biro (second defendant) gifted the plaint properties to her sons (grouped as first defendant).
Property in suit consisted of: 1) 253 bighas of Khas land; 2) a half share in 3 bighas 19 biswas; 3) a share in certain shamlat property.
Defendants claimed Harnam Singh gifted 123 bighas of the Khas land absolutely to Mst. Biro.
A house was not included in the gift by Mst. Biro to her sons.

Description of the house: tiny dwelling, distance between door of Sabbat and Darwaja about two karams (eleven feet), one Jhallani opening into Sabbat, no other roofed portion except compound for cattle; lived in by Mst. Biro and her three sons.
Harnam Singh had mortgaged a part of his estate and placed mortgagees in possession; after his death, some collaterals took possession of unencumbered portion.

Mst. Biro instituted two suits: one for possession against collaterals (including present plaintiffs or predecessors), and one for declaration against mortgagees, joining collaterals; succeeded on ground that property was not ancestral (Exhibits DD and DF).

Trial Court (Sub-Judge 1st Class, Mansa, 10th August 1948): held property not ancestral on admission of plaintiffs' counsel; daughters' sons succeed after her to exclusion of plaintiffs; gift accelerated estate; dismissed suit.
Lower Appellate Court (Additional District Judge, Bhatinda, 21st September 1949): upheld not ancestral (not contested); house not included in gift, so decreed plaintiffs' claim for that part.

High Court (Patiala and East Punjab States Union, 27th June 1950): upheld not ancestral (conceded); house not included but small part, retention does not indicate intention not to efface herself; plaintiffs collaterals in fifth degree; property not ancestral so daughters' sons nearest heirs; gift accelerated estate despite house exclusion; reversed lower appellate, restored trial court decree.
Supreme Court: plaintiffs' counsel tried to reopen not ancestral finding but not allowed as mixed question of law and fact conceded in lower courts; res judicata from prior suits.
Parties are agricultural Jats governed by Punjab custom.
Plaintiffs are collaterals of the fifth degree (per High Court), claimed as seventh by defendants.

legal_issues.text: Whether the property was ancestral (conceded as not by all courts).
Under Punjab custom for agricultural Jats, whether daughter's sons exclude father's collaterals as heirs to non-ancestral property after daughter.
Whether the gift by daughter Mst. Biro to her sons operated as surrender/acceleration of her estate, despite retention of a small house.

petitioner_arguments.text: Property is ancestral; daughter got only life estate; gift will not affect reversionary rights of plaintiffs as presumptive reversioners.
Tried to reopen finding that property not ancestral.
No acceleration/surrender because house not included in gift to sons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Paragraph 64 of Rattigan's Digest (no female can permanently alienate)

respondent_arguments.text: According to customary law, collaterals beyond fifth degree not heirs in presence of daughter and her line; plaintiffs seventh degree.
Property was not ancestral; plaintiffs cannot challenge daughter's alienation.
Harnam Singh gifted 123 bighas absolutely to Mst. Biro.

court_reasoning.text: Not ancestral conceded in all courts; mixed question of law and fact; res judicata from prior suits (Exhibits DD, DF).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Whole land in dispute not ancestral.

court_reasoning.text: Under Punjab custom (Rattigan para 23(2), Roe and Rattigan p.61): daughter preferred to collaterals for acquired property but as limited heir; succeeds merely to pass to her male issue; her sons exclude collaterals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sons take as if descent in male line; supported by Lehna v. Mst. Thakri and Lal Singh v. Roor Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Gift to sons was acceleration/surrender; retention of tiny house (small part of 253 bighas) does not invalidate as omission due to oversight; intention to efface completely shown by gifting absolute portion too.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mulla's Hindu Law p.217: omission of small portion does not affect bona fide surrender.

holdings.text: Daughter's sons exclude father's collaterals under custom for non-ancestral property.
Gift operated to accelerate succession to sons despite house retention.

precedents_cited.relevance: Daughters' sons and descendants exclude collaterals even for ancestral property (Full Bench, Punjab Chief Court).
For non-ancestral property, daughters preferred to collaterals; sons exclude collaterals.

statutes_cited.name: Rattigan's Digest of Customary Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Daughter preferred for acquired property but limited; no permanent alienation by female.

statutes_cited.name: Roe and Rattigan's Tribal Law of the Punjab
statutes_cited.relevance: Daughter succeeds as means to pass to her sons; limited like widow.

statutes_cited.name: Mulla's Hindu Law
statutes_cited.relevance: Omission of small portion does not affect validity of bona fide surrender.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment, restoring trial court decree dismissing plaintiffs' suit for declaration that gift does not affect their reversionary rights; gift accelerated estate to sons under custom.

key_quotes.text: "Where a succession of a married daughter is allowed, the general principle is that she succeeds not as an ordinary heir, but merely as the means of passing on the property to another male..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains limited nature of daughter's estate under Punjab custom.

key_quotes.text: "But the omission, due to ignorance or to oversight, of a small portion of the whole property does not affect the validity of the surrender when it is otherwise bona fide."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies acceleration despite house retention (from Mulla's Hindu Law).

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of gift to sons.
